author: sky.cactus
content: I'm curious to get a core dev temperature check on a stuck (not stolen) ETH recovery EIP.  The topic has been discussed at length in the past so we don't have to debate the merits/arguments here, I'm just curious if it would be worth formalizing a proposal at this point, or if that would be a waste of effort.  The idea with the proposal is that it would come in the form of a one-time irregular state change that addresses one or more specific classes of verifiably stuck funds and one or more scripts that anyone can run off-chain to validate that the change is in fact legitimate.

author: jadler2664
content: I disagree for one reason: "one-time." Either never do it, or make it part of the social contract that sufficiently significant provably stuck funds can be recovered via hard forks. While it might be difficult to make repeated instances of unlocking stuck funds fair, doing it only one time is by definition unfair and non-neutral.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, by "one-time" I just meant that an EIP that resolved stuck funds would be a one-off thing, not an automatically recurring thing.  I'm not against having multiple instances of these one-off things over time.  I *would* expect that they become more and more rare with time as the expectation is that the community should be learning from mistakes over time.  So maybe we address the JS address truncation stuck funds issue from before, but we wouldn't address that specific instance of stuck funds again in the future.

author: timbeiko
content: My 2c is the community has already signalled that they want it to ‚Äúbecome more rare‚Äù when The DAO (~15% of supply) went through and the Parity Multisig (~1%?) didn‚Äôt. author: holiman
content:
I was once in the camp of "sure, might be doable and ethically acceptable". Then over time, I saw more complexities. So certain cases are clear-cut: 1) easy to determine rightful owner, 2) easy to on-chain prove the asset-loss (e.g. 0-created contracts, it's easy to verify a sender+nonce against address. 3) easy to restore

Many other cases are not as simple. For example, someone who sent to 0-address. Hard to verify on-chain, but easy off-chain. Or: some people have deployed 'broken' contracts, where, due to some programming error, the funds are stuck. It can can be proven, by static analysis, that the funds are stuck. But non-trivial even off-chain. And many cases where it's hard to know who the owner should be. Like funds in a contract that cannot be emptied. Should they belong to the contract owner or the senders? For the splitter-contract -- the latter, for others, maybe the former. 
And lastly, there are all cases of sending to typo-addresses, where someone can prove that "there's just one byte off here, so it's most certainly meant for me". 

There are just _so_ many different classes, that I think it's a pandora's box, and we should avoid it. Could have been done three years ago, maybe, but we're not there any longer

author: sky.cactus
content:
I agree that the effort involved in validating claims is high.  I think we could offload the work of "proof" and script authoring to others pretty easily (there is definitely enough financial incentive) but I think you are correct that there would be significant burden on core devs to validate the claims/proofs and filter out the dubious ones.

I'm not fully convinced the social good of restoring people with stuck ETH is lower than the verification/filtering cost on core developers, but I definitely appreciate the argument.

author: chfast

We propose the **EIP-3541 to be included in London**. It itself is rather simple change, but it is part of bigger EIP-3540.

The EIP-3540 defines Ethereum Object Format (EOF) and for requires two hard fork to be deployed. The EIP-3541 being the first of two.

This is going to be discussed on today's ACD, but I can answer questions here before and after the call.

EIP-3540: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/3540
EIP-3541: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/3541

author: 0xraino
content: I think it's worth looking into ways in which an n-part EIP can be done in 1 part. In this case, could we not just signal ahead of time that a contract with that leading byte might break? If someone trolls us and deploys a contract with that leading byte prior to this EIP, the odds of them also crafting it such that it can exploit an _as yet undefined_ metadata are minuscule.

author: axic3354
content: The biggest problem is something else: having deployed code with the header before the fork introducing it is enabled. In the timeframe between a final version of the specification is released and the hard fork goes live, anyone can deploy code with such a header and avoid any validation. After the fork those accounts are deemed valid, yet they may not be. With rejecting a starting byte in the first fork it is possible to select a prefix which makes this problem go away. Basically we have not found a reasonable way to have deploy time validation without this two fork approach. (Earlier proposals were suggesting to add a version field into the account instead.)

author: 0xraino
content: Ah yes, they could easily watch the spec for it being final and then exploit it with certainty.

author: axic3354
content: And to clarify the "we" here, credit goes to <@456226577798135808> for coming up with the two-fork idea.

author: holiman
content: Yeah in this particular case, there's a very compelling reason to to do it in two steps

author: holiman
content: And it doesn't hurt that the first step is very very simple

author: chfast
content:
In other words: we are doing 2 HF to in the end has guarantee that all deployed EOF-prefixed bytecode are valid. For this we freeze first byte of the prefix in HF1. After HF1 nobody can deploy the yet unknown full EOF-prefix. And then we select the remaining magic bytes by inspecting all deployed contracts.

This is vulnerable to some trolling, but gives us much more welcome property.
